channel.title: NASA Image of the Day
channel.description: The latest NASA "Image of the Day" image.

item.title: Hubble Spots Two Interacting Galaxies Defying Cosmic Convention
item.description: Hubble spots two interacting galaxies some 60 million light-years away in the constellation of Leo.

item.title: Dr. Ellen Ochoa on the Flight Deck of Shuttle Atlantis
item.description: On April 15, 2002, STS-110 Mission Specialist Ellen Ochoa works at the Remote Manipulator System controls on the aft flight deck of space shuttle Atlantis. Dr. Ochoa, a veteran astronaut, is currently the 11th director of Johnson Space Center. She became the first Hispanic woman to go to space when she served on the STS-56 mission.

item.title: Space Station View of Mount Etna Erupting
item.description: The Expedition 50 crew aboard the International Space Station had a nighttime view from orbit of Europe's most active volcano, Mount Etna, erupting on March 19, 2017. Astronaut Thomas Pesquet of ESA captured this image, writing, "Mount Etna, in Sicily. The volcano is currently erupting and the molten ava is visible from space, at night!"

item.title: Photographer Carla Thomas on a Supersonic Flight
item.description: “Armstrong Flight Research Center chief pilot Nils Larson and I were flying supersonic runs to note the handling qualities between the single seat and two seat F/A-18 aircraft for the Sonic Booms in Atmospheric Turbulence, or SonicBAT program," said Carla Thomas, one of NASA's two female in-flight photographers.

item.title: Mackenzie River in Canada's Northwest Territories
item.description: This view, acquired on Nov. 7, 2016, by the Operational Land Imager (OLI) on Landsat 8, shows a portion of Canada's Mackenzie River Delta and the town of Inuvik, home to more than 3,000 people. A frozen highway -- 194 kilometers (120 miles) long -- runs between the remote outposts of Inuvik and Tuktoyaktuk along the river’s East Channel.

item.title: Dublin at Night
item.description: Expedition 50 Commander Shane Kimbrough of NASA shared this nighttime image of Dublin on March 17, 2017, writing, "Happy #StPatricksDay Spectacular #Dublin, Ireland captured by @thom_astro from @Space_Station. Enjoy the #StPatricksFest Parade down there!"

item.title: Annie Easley, Computer Scientist and Mathematician
item.description: Annie Easley at NASA Glenn Research Center. In 1955, Easley began her career at NASA, then the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics (NACA), as a human computer performing complex mathematical calculations.

item.title: NASA's Webb Telescope Ghostly 'Lights Out' Inspection
item.description: The technicians who are inspecting the telescope and its expansive golden mirrors look like ghostly wraiths in this image as they conduct a "lights out inspection" in the Spacecraft Systems Development and Integration Facility (SSDIF) at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Maryland.

item.title: Traffic-free and Sky-high
item.description: The Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) on the Aqua satellite captured this natural-color image of cloud streets over the Barents Sea and Mezhdusharsky Island on March 7, 2017. Such formations occur frequently in the region in late winter.

item.title: The Big One
item.description: Mimas' gigantic crater Herschel lies near the moon's limb in this Cassini view.

item.title: Hubble Homes In on a Hypergiant's Home
item.description: The super star cluster Westerlund 1, only 15,000 light-years away in our Milky Way neighborhood, hosts one of the largest stars ever discovered.

item.title: NASA's Orion Spacecraft Parachutes Tested at U.S. Army Yuma Proving Ground
item.description: Engineers Successfully Test the Parachutes for NASA's Orion Spacecraft at the U.S. Army Yuma Proving Ground

item.title: Women Scientists at NASA in January 1959
item.description: January 1959. Women Scientists Lucille Coltrane, Jean Clark Keating, Katherine Cullie Speegle, Doris 'Dot' Lee, Ruth Whitman, and Emily Stephens Mueller.

item.title: A Mass of Viscous Flow Features
item.description: Viscous, lobate flow features are commonly found at the bases of slopes in the mid-latitudes of Mars, and are often associated with gullies.

item.title: Technicians Secure the Protective Covering Around Cygnus
item.description: In the Space Station Processing Facility high bay at NASA's Kennedy Space Center in Florida, the Orbital ATK Cygnus pressurized cargo module is secured the KAMAG transporter and the crane has been removed.

item.title: Hubble Showcases a Remarkable Galactic Hybrid
item.description: UGC 12591's classification straddles somewhere between a lenticular and a spiral galaxy. It lies just under 400 million light-years from us in the Pisces–Perseus Supercluster.

item.title: Pearl Young at Langley's Flight Instrumentation Facility, March 1929
item.description: In this March 29, 1929 photograph, Pearl I. Young is working in the Langley Memorial Aeronautical Laboratory's Flight Instrumentation Facility (Building 1202). Young was the first woman hired as a technical employee, a physicist at the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics and the second female physicist working for the federal government.

item.title: Full-Circle Vista With a Linear Shaped Martian Sand Dune
item.description: The left side of this 360-degree panorama from NASA's Curiosity Mars rover shows the long rows of ripples on a linear shaped dune in the Bagnold Dune Field on the northwestern flank of Mount Sharp.

item.title: Glaciers Ebb on South Georgia Island
item.description: Frequent cloud cover in the southern Atlantic Ocean often obscures satellite images of South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands. But occasionally the clouds give way. On September 14, 2016, the Operational Land Imager (OLI) on Landsat 8 captured natural-color images of South Georgia Island, where several glaciers are in retreat.

item.title: Images of the Sun From the GOES-16 Satellite
item.description: These images of the sun were captured at the same time on January 29, 2017 by the six channels on the Solar Ultraviolet Imager or SUVI instrument aboard NOAA’s GOES-16 satellite. Data from SUVI will provide an estimation of coronal plasma temperatures and emission measurements which are important to space weather forecasting.

item.title: Orion Spacecraft Progress Continues With Installation of Module to Test Propulsion Systems
item.description: On Feb. 22, engineers successfully installed ESA’s European Service Module Propulsion Qualification Module (PQM) at NASA’s White Sands Test Facility in New Mexico that was delivered by Airbus – ESA’s prime contractor for the Service Module. The module will be equipped with a total of 21 engines to support NASA’s Orion spacecraft.

item.title: Charles T. Smoot
item.description: Charles Smoot was employed by NASA’s Marshall Space Flight Center where he began laying the foundation of a cooperative program targeting qualified African American students from universities across the nation.

item.title: Sounding Rocket Launches to Study Auroras
item.description: A NASA Black Brant IX sounding rocket soars skyward into an aurora over Alaska following a 5:14 a.m. EST, Feb. 22, 2017 launch from the Poker Flat Research Range in Alaska. The rocket carried an Ionospheric Structuring: In Situ and Groundbased Low Altitude StudieS (ISINGLASS) instrumented payload examining the structure of an aurora.

item.title: Rays of Creusa
item.description: When viewed from a distance with the sun directly behind Cassini, the larger, brighter craters really stand out on moons like Dione.

item.title: Liftoff of SpaceX Falcon 9 and Dragon From Launch Complex 39A
item.description: A SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket lifts off from Launch Complex 39A at NASA's Kennedy Space Center in Florida. This is the company's 10th commercial resupply services mission to the International Space Station. Liftoff was at 9:39 a.m. EST from the historic launch site now operated by SpaceX under a property agreement with NASA.

item.title: Falcon 9 Rocket With Dragon Spacecraft Vertical at Launch Complex 39A
item.description: NASA provider SpaceX's Falcon 9 rocket and Dragon spacecraft are vertical at Launch Complex 39A at NASA’s Kennedy Space Center in Florida. Liftoff of SpaceX's tenth Commercial Resupply Services cargo mission to the International Space Station is scheduled for 10:01 a.m. EST on Saturday, Feb. 18, 2017.

item.title: Thomas Byrdsong, Aerospace Engineer at NASA Langley Research Center
item.description: On March 2, 1963 Engineer Thomas Byrdsong checks the Apollo/Saturn 1B Ground-wind-loads model in the Transonic Dynamics Tunnel at Langley Research Center in Hampton, Virginia.

item.title: Glacial 'Aftershock' Spawns Antarctic Iceberg
item.description: Pine Island Glacier has shed another block of ice into Antarctic waters. The loss was tiny compared to the icebergs that broke off in 2014 and 2015, but the event is further evidence of the ice shelf’s fragility.

item.title: Space Station Flight Over Venice
item.description: Expedition 50 Flight Engineer Thomas Pesquet of the European Space Agency shared this photograph from the International Space Station on Feb. 14, 2017, writing, "Venice, city of gondoliers and the lovers they carry along the canals. Happy Valentine's Day!"

item.title: F for Fabulous
item.description: When seen up close, the F ring of Saturn resolves into multiple dusty strands. This Cassini view shows three bright strands and a very faint fourth strand off to the right.

item.title: Hubble Sees Spiral in Andromeda
item.description: The Andromeda constellation is one of the 88 modern constellations and should not be confused with our neighboring Andromeda Galaxy.

item.title: Jeanette A. Scissum, Scientist and Mathematician at NASA Marshall
item.description: Jeanette Scissum joined NASA’s Marshall Space Flight Center in 1964 after earning bachelor's and master's degrees in mathematics from Alabama A&M University. Scissum published a NASA report in 1967, “Survey of Solar Cycle Prediction Models,” which put forward techniques for improved forecasting of the sunspot cycle.

item.title: Sunrise at Rogers Dry Lake
item.description: A sunrise photo of Edwards Air Force Base’s Rogers Dry Lake was taken after heavy rainfall in southern California. NASA’s Armstrong Flight Research Center is seen in the foreground.

item.title: Antarctica’s Changing Larsen Ice Shelf
item.description: The Larsen Ice Shelf is situated along the northeastern coast of the Antarctic Peninsula, one of the fastest-warming places on the planet. In the past three decades, two large sections of the ice shelf (Larsen A and B) collapsed. A third section (Larsen C) seems like it may be on a similar trajectory, with a new iceberg poised to break away soon.

item.title: Potentially Hospitable Enceladus
item.description: Seen from outside, Enceladus appears to be like most of its sibling moons: cold, icy and inhospitable.

item.title: Hubble Captures Brilliant Star Death in “Rotten Egg” Nebula
item.description: The Calabash Nebula, pictured here is a spectacular example of the death of a low-mass star like the sun.

item.title: Looking Back: Dr. George Carruthers and Apollo 16 Far Ultraviolet Camera/Spectrograph
item.description: Dr. George Carruthers, right, and William Conway, a project manager at the Naval Research Institute, examine the gold-plated ultraviolet camera/spectrograph, the first moon-based observatory that Carruthers developed for the Apollo 16 mission. Apollo 16 astronauts placed the observatory on the moon in April 1972.

item.title: Lake Powell and Grand Staircase-Escalante
item.description: This panorama, photographed by an astronaut aboard the International Space Station, shows nearly the full length of Lake Powell, the reservoir on the Colorado River in southern Utah and northern Arizona. Note that the ISS was north of the lake at the time, so in this view south is at the top left of the image.

item.title: NASA Day of Remembrance
item.description: Martha Chaffee, widow of Roger Chaffee, Sheryl Chaffee, daughter, and Roger Purvenas, son of Sheryl Chaffee, left, along with acting NASA Administrator Robert Lightfoot, right, place wreaths at the graves of Apollo 1 crewmembers Virgil "Gus" Grissom and Roger Chaffee as part of NASA's Day of Remembrance, Tuesday, Jan. 31, 2017.

item.title: Coy Dione
item.description: Dione's lit hemisphere faces away from Cassini's camera, yet the moon's darkened surface features are dimly illuminated in this image, due to Saturnshine.

item.title: Apollo 1 Crew Honored
item.description: Astronauts, from the left, Gus Grissom, Ed White II and Roger Chaffee stand near Cape Kennedy's Launch Complex 34 during training for Apollo 1 in January 1967.

item.title: January 1986 - Voyager 2 Flyby of Miranda
item.description: Uranus' moon Miranda is shown in a computer-assembled mosaic of images obtained Jan. 24, 1986, by the Voyager 2 spacecraft. Miranda is the innermost and smallest of the five major Uranian satellites, just 480 kilometers (about 300 miles) in diameter. Nine images were combined to obtain this full-disc, south-polar view.

item.title: Juno’s Close Look at a Little Red Spot
item.description: The JunoCam imager on NASA’s Juno spacecraft snapped this shot of Jupiter’s northern latitudes.

item.title: NASA Simulates Orion Spacecraft Launch Conditions for Crew
item.description: In a lab at NASA’s Johnson Space Center in Houston, engineers simulated conditions that astronauts in space suits would experience when the Orion spacecraft is vibrating during launch atop the agency’s powerful Space Launch System rocket on its way to deep space destinations.

item.title: New Weather Satellite Sends First Images of Earth
item.description: The release of the first images today from NOAA’s newest satellite, GOES-16, is the latest step in a new age of weather satellites. This composite color full-disk visible image is from 1:07 p.m. EDT on Jan. 15, 2017, and was created using several of the 16 spectral channels available on the GOES-16 Advanced Baseline Imager (ABI) instrument.

item.title: Daphnis Up Close
item.description: The wavemaker moon, Daphnis, is featured in this view, taken as NASA's Cassini spacecraft made one of its ring-grazing passes over the outer edges of Saturn's rings on Jan. 16, 2017.

item.title: Possible Signs of Ancient Drying in Martian Rock
item.description: A grid of small polygons on the Martian rock surface near the right edge of this view may have originated as cracks in drying mud more than 3 billion years ago.

item.title: NASA Astronaut Shane Kimbrough on Jan. 13 Spacewalk
item.description: Expedition 50 Commander Shane Kimbrough of NASA at work outside the International Space Station on Jan. 13, 2017, in a photo taken by fellow spacewalker Thomas Pesquet of ESA. The two astronauts successfully installed three new adapter plates and hooked up electrical connections for three of the six new lithium-ion batteries on the station.

item.title: Crescent Jupiter with the Great Red Spot
item.description: This image of a crescent Jupiter and the iconic Great Red Spot was created by a citizen scientist (Roman Tkachenko) using data from Juno's JunoCam instrument.

item.title: Well-Preserved Impact Ejecta on Mars
item.description: This image of a well-preserved unnamed elliptical crater in Terra Sabaea, is illustrative of the complexity of ejecta deposits forming as a by-product of the impact process that shapes much of the surface of Mars.

item.title: NASA Astronaut Peggy Whitson's 7th Spacewalk
item.description: Flight Engineer Peggy Whitson along with Expedition 50 Commander Shane Kimbrough successfully installed three new adapter plates and hooked up electrical connections for three of the six new lithium-ion batteries on the International Space Station during last week's spacewalk.

item.title: Rocky Mountains From Orbit
item.description: Expedition 50 Flight Engineer Thomas Pesquet of the European Space Agency photographed the Rocky Mountains from his vantage point in low Earth orbit aboard the International Space Station. He shared the image with his social media followers on Jan. 9, 2017, writing, "the Rocky mountains are a step too high – even for the clouds to cross."

item.title: Breaking Boundaries in New Engine Designs
item.description: In an effort to improve fuel efficiency, NASA and the aircraft industry are rethinking aircraft design.

item.title: Your Home Planet, as Seen From Mars
item.description: Here is a view of Earth and its moon, as seen from Mars. It combines two images acquired on Nov. 20, 2016, by the HiRISE camera on NASA's Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter, with brightness adjusted separately for Earth and the moon to show details on both bodies.

item.title: Abell 3411 and Abell 3412: Astronomers Discover Powerful Cosmic Double Whammy
item.description: Astronomers have discovered what happens when the eruption from a supermassive black hole is swept up by the collision and merger of two galaxy clusters.

item.title: Hues in a Crater Slope
item.description: Impact craters expose the subsurface materials on the steep slopes of Mars. However, these slopes often experience rockfalls and debris avalanches that keep the surface clean of dust, revealing a variety of hues, like in this enhanced-color image from NASA's Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter, representing different rock types.

item.title: Send in the Clouds
item.description: Floating high above the hydrocarbon lakes, wispy clouds have finally started to return to Titan's northern latitudes.

item.title: Small Satellite Deployed From the Space Station
item.description: A satellite is ejected from the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA) Small Satellite Orbital Deployer on the International Space Station on Dec. 19, 2016. The satellite is actually two small satellites that, once at a safe distance from the station, separated from each other, but were still connected by a 100-meter-long Kevlar tether.

item.title: Hubble Gazes at a Cosmic Megamaser
item.description: This galaxy acts as an astronomical laser, beaming out microwave emission rather than visible light.

item.title: Basking in Light
item.description: Sunlight truly has come to Saturn's north pole. The whole northern region is bathed in sunlight in this view from late 2016, feeble though the light may be at Saturn's distant domain in the solar system.
